instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD1: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD1? PP2V5_NAND_SSD1 is a power rail that powers the soldered on SSDs.
definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15” Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD? PP2V5_NAND_SSD is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message:
Hey, first post here.

Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with slight liquid spill (some red wine) no power, 20V 0.200A on the USB Charger. DFU revive doesn't work and ends with [I]AMRestoreErrorDomain – 0x6[/I]

Spill is [I]around[/I] <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD1_SNS</SIGNAL> 12.66V
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0.06V
<SIGNAL>SSD1_VR_P2V5_PGOOD</SIGNAL>  0.06V
<SIGNAL>SSD1_VR_P2V5_EN_R</SIGNAL> 1.79V

<CAPACITOR>C9073</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C9080</CAPACITOR> .337 Diode
L9080 / L9081 0.00Ohm / .002 Diode

Is it <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> or <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> which's dead? <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> gets hotter than <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>, but not crazy hot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Liquid spill under <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> may already killed SSD.
<CHIP>U9080</CHIP> is not shorted I suppose, but damaged.
Lift it and check where the short remains.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message: Thank you! Where to check best without <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>? Should I Inject 2.5V on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message:
If still short there, you can start injexting with 1V; may be sufficient to find the culprit.
Slowly increase the voltage, if needed, no more than 3V.
Very likely NAND chip fried.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message:
Lifted <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>, doesn't look corroded.
Short is still present on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL>. Injected 1 - 3V. SSD gets warm at 3V, but only 30°C.

Still L9080 / L9081 0.00Ohm / .002 Diode

[ATTACH alt="<SIGNAL>IMG_0153</SIGNAL>.jpg"]60426[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message:
Which is the current consumption from PSU at 2V?
Use powerful cables; don't need to heat them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 86355, member: 682"]
Which is the current consumption from PSU at 2V?
[/QUOTE]

PSU@2V takes 0,38A

[QUOTE]Use powerful cables; don't need to heat them.[/QUOTE]

What do you mean? The cable used for injection? Thats 0,75mm²

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message:
That means less than 1W, not easy to detect heat.
Try with 3V and use thermal cam to detect the culprit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message: We used FLIR one (shit) and the only part which got [I]hot[/I] was SSD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message:
Need to detect the particular chip that heats more than other.
However, you should know that replacing NANDs may be waste of time.

Please, do not quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message: So there's nothing left to do than replace <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>? Or which particular chip should be find? Everything on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message:
4 NAND chips are powered from the same rail.
You should detect the bad one.

Onboard SSD repair is not an easy job; need donor board same model, same chip position.
You can find some videos on Internet.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0,06V
threads.message: Okay, its <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> which gets hot. I´ll come back to here if NAND is switched.
